δ𝛿\delta-Sequences and Evaluation Codes defined by Plane Valuations at Infinity

C. Galindo and F. Monserrat C. Galindo: Departament de Matemàtiques, Universitat Jaume I, Campus de Riu Sec. s/n, 12071 Castelló (Spain); F. Monserrat: Instituto Universitario de Matemática Pura y Aplicada, Universidad Politécnica de Valencia, Camino de Vera s/n, 46022 Valencia (Spain) galindo@mat.uji.es    framonde@mat.upv.es
Abstract.

We introduce the concept of δ𝛿\delta-sequence. A δ𝛿\delta-sequence ΔΔ\Delta generates a well-ordered semigroup S𝑆S in ℤ2superscriptℤ2\mathbb{Z}^{2} or ℝℝ\mathbb{R}. We show how to construct (and compute parameters) for the dual code of any evaluation code associated with a weight function defined by ΔΔ\Delta from the polynomial ring in two indeterminates to a semigroup S𝑆S as above. We prove that this is a simple procedure which can be understood by considering a particular class of valuations of function fields of surfaces, called plane valuations at infinity. We also give algorithms to construct an unlimited number of δ𝛿\delta-sequences of the different existing types, and so this paper provides the tools to know and use a new large set of codes.

1991 Mathematics Subject Classification:
94B27, 14B05, 11T71
Supported by Spain Ministry of Education MTM2007-64704, JCyL VA025A07 and Bancaixa P1-1A2005-08. We thank C. Munuera and F. Torres for helpful discussions.

1. Introduction

BCH and Reed-Solomon codes can be decoded from the sixties by using the Berlekamp-Massey algorithm [6, 25]. A paper by Sakata [33] allowed to derive the Berlekamp-Massey-Sakata algorithm which can be used to efficiently decode certain Algebraic Geometry codes on curves [39]. Indeed, this last algorithm allows us to get fast implementations of the modified algorithm of [22, 37] (see [23, 21]) and of the majority voting scheme for unknown syndromes of Feng and Rao [11] (see [23, 24, 34, 35]). For a survey on the decoding of Algebraic Geometry codes one can see [20].

The so-called order functions were introduced in [19], which in this initial stage had as image set a sub-semigroup of the set of nonnegative integers. An order function defines a filtration of vector spaces contained in its definition domain which, together with an evaluation map, provide two families of error correcting codes (evaluation codes and their duals). We note that the one-point geometric Goppa codes or weighted Reed-Muller codes can be regarded as codes given by order functions.

A type of particularly useful order functions are the weight functions. Goppa distance and Feng-Rao distances (also called order bounds) are lower bounds for the minimum distance of their associated dual codes which can be decoded by using the mentioned Berlekamp-Massey-Sakata algorithm, correcting a number of errors that depends on the above bounds [19, 40]. Furthermore, Matsumoto in [26] proved that their associated order domains are affine coordinate rings of algebraic curves with exactly one place at infinity.

Recently in [16], the concept of order function (and the related ones of weight function and order domain) have been enlarged by admitting that the image of those functions can be a well-ordered semigroup. Order domains are close to Groebner algebras and they allow to use the theory of Groebner basis [5]. This enlargement provides a greater variety of evaluation codes and it has the same advantages (bounds of minimum distance and fast decoding) that we had with the first defined concept.

Weight functions were introduced to give an elementary treatment to some Algebraic Geometry codes. Nevertheless, a deeper study of these functions with the help of Algebraic Geometry may derive in obtaining new good linear codes. This is the line of this paper. The main notion we introduce is an extension to elements in ℤ2superscriptℤ2\mathbb{Z}^{2}, ℚℚ\mathbb{Q} and ℝℝ\mathbb{R} of the classical concept of δ𝛿\delta-sequence defined by the Abhyankar-Moh conditions. These δ𝛿\delta-sequences provide valuations in function fields of surfaces (related to curves with only one place at infinity) and, for that reason, weight functions. This allows us to focus our development to an application in Coding Theory that consists of studying the evaluation codes given by those weight functions.

Valuations and weight functions are very close objects as one can see in [40]. Apart from the simpler case of curves, it is only available a classification of valuations of function fields of nonsingular surfaces (also called plane valuations) [43, 38, 17], that allows us to decide which of them are suitable for providing, in an explicit manner, order domains and evaluation codes. The first examples that use that classification were given in [40] and a more systematic development can be found in [15]. Although both papers have the same background, they provide different types of examples and it seems that examples in [40] cannot be obtained from the development in [15]. In this paper we give theoretic foundations to provide families of weight functions that contain as particular cases the examples concerning plane valuations given in [40]. This leads us to a deeper knowledge of the involved evaluation codes what allows us to get explicitly a large set of codes (and associated parameters) from a simple input which can be easily determined.

More explicitly, in [15] it is assumed that R𝑅R is a 2-dimensional Noetherian regular local ring with quotient field K𝐾K and that R𝑅R has an algebraically closed coefficient field k𝑘k of arbitrary characteristic. By picking a plane valuation ν𝜈\nu (of K𝐾K centered at R𝑅R) belonging to any type of the above mentioned classification, except the so called divisorial valuations, it is found an order domain D𝐷D attached to the weight function −ν𝜈-\nu, whose image semigroup is the value semigroup S:={f∈R∖{0}|ν​(f)≥0}assign𝑆conditional-set𝑓𝑅0𝜈𝑓0S:=\{f\in R\setminus\{0\}|\nu(f)\geq 0\} of ν𝜈\nu. Moreover, in that paper parametric equations and examples of those weight functions, and also bounds for the minimum distance of the corresponding dual evaluation codes are given. In this paper, we shall consider a different point of view. This is to look for weight functions, whose order domain is the polynomial ring in two indeterminates T:=k​[x,y]assign𝑇𝑘𝑥𝑦T:=k[x,y], derived from valuations of the quotient field k​(x,y)𝑘𝑥𝑦k(x,y) of T𝑇T, where, now, k𝑘k needs not be algebraically closed. The mentioned paper [40] provides some examples of this type with monomial and non-monomial associated ordering, but no additional explanation is supplied.

We shall show that the key to get this last type of weight functions (with value semigroup generated by the so-called δ𝛿\delta-sequences) is to use for their construction certain class of plane valuations, that we shall name plane valuations at infinity (see Definition 4.5 and Proposition 4.10). These valuations are those given by certain families of infinitely many plane curves, all of them having only one place at infinity. This constitutes, in some sense, an extension of the above result by Matsumoto.

Our development allows us to reach our main goal, which consists of explicitly constructing weight functions from T𝑇T, attached to plane valuations at infinity, for which it is easy to determine its image semigroup and the filtration of vector spaces in T𝑇T we need to construct the codes, and either to bound or to determine the corresponding Feng-Rao and Goppa distances (see Theorems 4.9 and 5.3 and Proposition 5.4). The unique input to compute those data is the so-called δ𝛿\delta-sequence of the weight function which also determines it. It is also worth adding that the obtained image semigroups have a behavior close to the one of telescopic semigroups and that the so-called approximates of the valuation at infinity (see Definition 4.6) make easy the computation of the mentioned filtration.

The implementation of these new codes is very simple since to compute the data to use them is straightforward from the δ𝛿\delta-sequences that define the weight functions; this paper provides algorithms (if necessary) to get an unlimited number of δ𝛿\delta-sequences of any existing type. In fact, to provide a family of codes {Eα}α∈Ssubscriptsubscript𝐸𝛼𝛼𝑆\{E_{\alpha}\}_{\alpha\in S} and its dual family {Cα}α∈Ssubscriptsubscript𝐶𝛼𝛼𝑆\{C_{\alpha}\}_{\alpha\in S} with alphabet code k𝑘k (k𝑘k is any finite field), we only need to pick a δ𝛿\delta-sequence ΔΔ\Delta (Definition 4.7) and a set 𝔄𝔄\mathfrak{A} of n𝑛n different points in k2superscript𝑘2k^{2}. ΔΔ\Delta can be finite (included in ℤ2superscriptℤ2\mathbb{Z}^{2} or ℝℝ\mathbb{R}) or infinite (included in ℚℚ\mathbb{Q}); in the last case, we need only a finite subset of ΔΔ\Delta that depends on k𝑘k and 𝔄𝔄\mathfrak{A}. To obtain δ𝛿\delta-sequences is easy following the procedure given in Section 4.3. Moreover S𝑆S is the semigroup spanned by ΔΔ\Delta and must be ordered lexicographically when it is in ℤ2superscriptℤ2\mathbb{Z}^{2} and usually ordered otherwise. Eαsubscript𝐸𝛼E_{\alpha} is the image e​v​(Oα)𝑒𝑣subscript𝑂𝛼ev(O_{\alpha}) of a vector space Oαsubscript𝑂𝛼O_{\alpha} of k​[x,y]𝑘𝑥𝑦k[x,y], where e​v𝑒𝑣ev is the map e​v:k​[x,y]→kn:𝑒𝑣→𝑘𝑥𝑦superscript𝑘𝑛ev:k[x,y]\rightarrow k^{n} that evaluates polynomials at the points in 𝔄𝔄\mathfrak{A}. Cαsubscript𝐶𝛼C_{\alpha} is the dual vector space of Eαsubscript𝐸𝛼E_{\alpha}. Finally, bases for the spaces Oαsubscript𝑂𝛼O_{\alpha} can be computed without difficulty since they are formed by polynomials as in (3) (see the beginning of Section 4.3), where the exponents are obtained from ΔΔ\Delta by an algorithm similar to Euclid’s one (see the beginning of Section 4.2).

Next, we briefly describe the content of the paper. Valuations on function fields of surfaces and their classification are fundamental for understanding the development of this paper and Section 3 is devoted to provide a short summary for it. We only use a particular subset of these valuations, plane valuations at infinity. Although the definition is given in Section 4, to manipulate these valuations we need some knowledge about plane curves with only one place at infinity and this information is displayed in Section 2. The development of this section shortens Section 3 due to the closeness between them. Section 4 contains the core of the paper: we give the definition of δ𝛿\delta-sequence and algorithms for constructing δ𝛿\delta-sequences. We also explain the way to use them to get weight functions associated with valuations at infinity and how to compute bases of the vector spaces filtration needed to obtain the corresponding codes. There are δ𝛿\delta-sequences giving rise to valuations at infinity only for three of the five types of the above mentioned classification for plane valuations. These δ𝛿\delta-sequences provide weight functions with monomial and non-monomial corresponding orderings. Some examples are also supplied in this section. Finally, Section 5 studies the Feng-Rao and Goppa distances for dual codes given by δ𝛿\delta-sequences (see Theorem 5.3 and Proposition 5.4). A useful property to study these distances is that δ𝛿\delta-sequences generate semigroups similar to telescopic ones, which we call generalized telescopic semigroups. Moreover, the δ𝛿\delta-sequences which are in ℤ2superscriptℤ2{\mathbb{Z}}^{2} span simplicial semigroups and thus we can compute the least Feng-Rao distance using an algorithm by Ruano [32]. We end this paper proving, in Proposition 5.6, that Reed-Solomon codes are a particular case of codes given by δ𝛿\delta-sequences included in ℤ2superscriptℤ2\mathbb{Z}^{2} and giving several examples of dual codes (showing their parameters) defined by δ𝛿\delta-sequences of all mentioned types.

2. Plane curves with only one place at infinity

We devote this section to summarize several known results concerning plane curves with only one place at infinity because this geometric concept supports the definition of those weight functions that will be useful for our purposes. References for the subject are [4, 3, 36, 29, 41, 13]. Some of the results concerning this type of curves have been used by Campillo and Farrán in [8] for computing the Weierstrass semigroup and the least Feng-Rao distance of the corresponding Goppa codes attached to singular plane models for curves with only one place at infinity. We begin with the definition of a key concept for this paper. Denote by ℕ>(≥)​0subscriptℕabsent0\mathbb{N}_{>(\geq)0} the set of positive (nonnegative) integers.

A δ𝛿\delta-sequence in ℕ>0subscriptℕabsent0\mathbb{N}_{>0} is a finite sequence of positive integers Δ={δi}i=0gΔsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝛿𝑖𝑖0𝑔\Delta=\{\delta_{i}\}_{i=0}^{g}, g≥0𝑔0g\geq 0, satisfying the following three conditions

    For 1≤i≤g1𝑖𝑔1\leq i\leq g, ni​δisubscript𝑛𝑖subscript𝛿𝑖n_{i}\delta_{i} belongs to the semigroup generated by δ0,δ1,…,δi−1subscript𝛿0subscript𝛿1…subscript𝛿𝑖1\delta_{0},\delta_{1},\ldots,\delta_{i-1}, that we usually denote ⟨δ0,δ1,…,δi−1⟩subscript𝛿0subscript𝛿1…subscript𝛿𝑖1\langle\delta_{0},\delta_{1},\ldots,\delta_{i-1}\rangle.

Above conditions are usually called Abhyankar-Moh conditions. We denote by SΔsubscript𝑆ΔS_{\Delta} the sub-semigroup of ℕ≥0subscriptℕabsent0\mathbb{N}_{\geq 0} spanned by ΔΔ\Delta.

Along this paper ℙk2superscriptsubscriptℙ𝑘2\mathbb{P}_{k}^{2} (or ℙ2superscriptℙ2\mathbb{P}^{2} for short) stands for the projective plane over a field k𝑘k of arbitrary characteristic. Now, let us state the definition of plane curve with only one place at infinity.

Definition 2.2.

Let L𝐿L be the line at infinity in the compactification of the affine plane to ℙ2superscriptℙ2\mathbb{P}^{2}. Let C𝐶C be a projective absolutely irreducible curve of ℙ2superscriptℙ2\mathbb{P}^{2} (i.e., irreducible as a curve in ℙk¯2subscriptsuperscriptℙ2¯𝑘\mathbb{P}^{2}_{\overline{k}}, k¯¯𝑘\overline{k} being the algebraic closure of k𝑘k). We shall say that C𝐶C has only one place at infinity if the intersection C∩L𝐶𝐿C\cap L is a single point p𝑝p (the one at infinity) and C𝐶C has only one branch at p𝑝p which is rational (that is, defined over k𝑘k).

Set C𝐶C a curve with only one place at infinity. Denote by K𝐾K the quotient field of the local ring 𝒪C,psubscript𝒪𝐶𝑝\mathcal{O}_{C,p}; the germ of C𝐶C at p𝑝p defines a discrete valuation on K𝐾K that we set νC,psubscript𝜈𝐶𝑝\nu_{C,p}, which allows us to state the following

Definition 2.3.

Let C𝐶C be a curve with only one place at infinity given by p𝑝p. The semigroup at infinity of C𝐶C is the following sub-semigroup of ℕ≥0subscriptℕabsent0\mathbb{N}_{\geq 0}:

SC,∞:={−νC,p​(h)|h∈T},assignsubscript𝑆𝐶conditional-setsubscript𝜈𝐶𝑝ℎℎ𝑇S_{C,\infty}:=\left\{-\nu_{C,p}(h)|h\in T\right\},

where T𝑇T is the k𝑘k-algebra 𝒪C​(C∖{p})subscript𝒪𝐶𝐶𝑝\mathcal{O}_{C}(C\setminus\{p\}).

For any curve C𝐶C with only one place at infinity, except when the characteristic of k𝑘k divides the degree of C𝐶C, it can be proved that there is a δ𝛿\delta-sequence in ℕ>0subscriptℕabsent0\mathbb{N}_{>0}, ΔΔ\Delta, such that SC,∞=SΔsubscript𝑆𝐶subscript𝑆ΔS_{C,\infty}=S_{\Delta} [4]. Conversely, as we shall precise later, for any field k𝑘k and any δ𝛿\delta-sequence in ℕ>0subscriptℕabsent0\mathbb{N}_{>0}, there exists a plane curve C𝐶C with only one place at infinity such that SΔ=SC,∞subscript𝑆Δsubscript𝑆𝐶S_{\Delta}=S_{C,\infty} and δ0subscript𝛿0\delta_{0} is the degree of C𝐶C.

C𝐶C has a singularity at p𝑝p, except when g=0𝑔0g=0. Consider the infinite sequence of morphisms

(1) ⋯→Xi+1→Xi→⋯→X1→X0:=ℙ2,→⋯subscript𝑋𝑖1→subscript𝑋𝑖→⋯→subscript𝑋1→subscript𝑋0assignsuperscriptℙ2\cdots\rightarrow X_{i+1}\rightarrow X_{i}\rightarrow\cdots\rightarrow X_{1}\rightarrow X_{0}:=\mathbb{P}^{2},

where X1→X0→subscript𝑋1subscript𝑋0X_{1}\rightarrow X_{0} is the blowing-up at p0:=passignsubscript𝑝0𝑝p_{0}:=p (the point at infinity) and, for each i≥1𝑖1i\geq 1, Xi+1→Xi→subscript𝑋𝑖1subscript𝑋𝑖X_{i+1}\rightarrow X_{i} denotes the blowing-up of Xisubscript𝑋𝑖X_{i} at the unique point pisubscript𝑝𝑖p_{i} which lies on the strict transform of C𝐶C and the exceptional divisor created by the preceding blowing-up; notice that pisubscript𝑝𝑖p_{i} is defined over k𝑘k, since the branch of C𝐶C at p𝑝p is rational. It is well-known that there exists a minimum integer n𝑛n such that, if π:Xn→ℙ2:𝜋→subscript𝑋𝑛superscriptℙ2\pi:X_{n}\rightarrow\mathbb{P}^{2} denotes the composition of the first n𝑛n blowing-ups, the germ of the strict transform of C𝐶C by π𝜋\pi at pnsubscript𝑝𝑛p_{n} becomes regular and transversal to the exceptional divisor. This gives the (minimal embedded) resolution of the germ of C𝐶C at p𝑝p. The essential information, the (topological) equisingularity class of the germ, can be given in terms of its sequence of Newton polygons [7, III.4] or by means of its dual graph (see [10] within a more general setting or [13] for a slightly different version). This information basically provides the number and the position of blowing-up centers of π𝜋\pi: these can be placed either on a free point (not an intersection of two exceptional divisors) or on a satellite point. In this last case, it is also important to know whether, or not, the blowing-up center belongs to the last but one created exceptional divisor. Thinking of blowing-up centers, we shall say that a center pisubscript𝑝𝑖p_{i} is proximate to other pjsubscript𝑝𝑗p_{j} whenever pisubscript𝑝𝑖p_{i} is on any strict transform of the divisor created after blowing-up at pjsubscript𝑝𝑗p_{j}.

The complete information of the resolution process can be described by means of the so-called Hamburger-Noether expansion (HNE for short) [7, 9], being this expansion specially useful when the characteristic of the field k𝑘k is positive. where the family {si}i=0gsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑠𝑖𝑖0𝑔\{s_{i}\}_{i=0}^{g}, s0=0subscript𝑠00s_{0}=0, of nonnegative integers is the set of indices corresponding to the free rows of the expression, that is those rows that express the blowing-ups at free points (they are those that have some nonzero aj​l∈ksubscript𝑎𝑗𝑙𝑘a_{jl}\in k) and the main goal (of the HNE) is that it gives local coordinates of the transform of the germ of C𝐶C at p𝑝p in each center of blowing-up. The local coordinates after {u′,v′}superscript𝑢′superscript𝑣′\{u^{\prime},v^{\prime}\} are {u′,(v′/u′)−a01}superscript𝑢′superscript𝑣′superscript𝑢′subscript𝑎01\{u^{\prime},(v^{\prime}/u^{\prime})-a_{01}\} and so on.

The dual graph ΓΓ\Gamma associated with the above germ of curve is a tree such that each vertex represents an exceptional divisor of the sequence π𝜋\pi and two vertices are joined by an edge whenever the corresponding divisors intersect. Additionally, we label each vertex with the minimal number of blowing-ups needed to create its corresponding exceptional divisor. The dual graph can be done by gluing by their vertices s​ti𝑠subscript𝑡𝑖st_{i} subgraphs ΓisubscriptΓ𝑖\Gamma_{i} (1≤i≤g)1𝑖𝑔(1\leq i\leq g) corresponding to blocks of data Bi={hsi−1−ki−1+1,hsi−1+1,hsi−1+2,…,hsi−1,ki}subscript𝐵𝑖subscriptℎsubscript𝑠𝑖1subscript𝑘𝑖11subscriptℎsubscript𝑠𝑖11subscriptℎsubscript𝑠𝑖12…subscriptℎsubscript𝑠𝑖1subscript𝑘𝑖B_{i}=\{h_{s_{i-1}}-k_{i-1}+1,h_{s_{i-1}+1},h_{s_{i-1}+2},\ldots,h_{s_{i}-1},k_{i}\} (with k0=0subscript𝑘00k_{0}=0), which represent the divisors involved in the part of HNE of the germ between two free rows. So, the dual graph has the shape depicted in Figure 1.

Set Esisubscript𝐸subscript𝑠𝑖E_{s_{i}} (1≤i≤g)1𝑖𝑔(1\leq i\leq g) the exceptional divisor obtained after blowing-up the last free point corresponding to the subgraph ΓisubscriptΓ𝑖\Gamma_{i}. It corresponds to the vertex ρisubscript𝜌𝑖\rho_{i} in the dual graph. An irreducible germ of curve at p𝑝p, ψ𝜓\psi, is said to have maximal contact of genus i𝑖i with the germ of C𝐶C at p𝑝p, if the strict transform of ψ𝜓\psi in the (corresponding germ of the) surface containing Esisubscript𝐸subscript𝑠𝑖E_{s_{i}} is not singular and meets transversely Esisubscript𝐸subscript𝑠𝑖E_{s_{i}} and no other exceptional curves.

Set (x,y)𝑥𝑦(x,y) coordinates in the chart Z≠0𝑍0Z\neq 0 and (u=y/x,v=1/x)formulae-sequence𝑢𝑦𝑥𝑣1𝑥(u=y/x,v=1/x) coordinates around the point at infinity. We end this section by collecting recent information about a particularly simple set of curves with only one place at infinity.

Definition 2.6.

An Abhyankar-Moh-Suzuki (A​M​S𝐴𝑀𝑆AMS for short) curve C𝐶C is a plane curve with only one place at infinity such that it is rational and nonsingular in its affine part.

The advantage of this type of curves is that their dual graphs are easily described [12] and their associated δ𝛿\delta-sequences in ℕ>0subscriptℕabsent0\mathbb{N}_{>0} are also very easy to compute: they are those sequences {δi}i=0gsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝛿𝑖𝑖0𝑔\{\delta_{i}\}_{i=0}^{g} of distinct positive integers such that δisubscript𝛿𝑖\delta_{i} divides δi−1subscript𝛿𝑖1\delta_{i-1} for all i=1,2,…,g𝑖12…𝑔i=1,2,\ldots,g and δg=1subscript𝛿𝑔1\delta_{g}=1 (this can be deduced from the proof of [27, Proposition 2]).

3. Valuations of function fields of surfaces

In this paper, we are concerned with weight functions given by certain type of valuations close to curves with only one place at infinity. For this reason, we devote this section to state the main facts related to valuations we shall need. See [42, 43, 1, 2, 38, 17] for some significant applications of valuation theory in algebraic geometry. Additional details to this section, following the same line of this paper, can be found in Section 3 of [15].

From now on, we shall set p𝑝p a point in ℙ2superscriptℙ2\mathbb{P}^{2}, R:=𝒪ℙ2,passign𝑅subscript𝒪superscriptℙ2𝑝R:=\mathcal{O}_{\mathbb{P}^{2},p} and K𝐾K the quotient field of R𝑅R.

Definition 3.1.

A valuation of the field K𝐾K is a mapping

ν:K∗(:=K∖{0})→G,:𝜈→annotatedsuperscript𝐾assignabsent𝐾0𝐺\nu:K^{*}(:=K\setminus\{0\})\rightarrow G,

where G𝐺G is a totally ordered group, such that it satisfies ν​(f+g)≥min⁡{ν​(f),ν​(g)}𝜈𝑓𝑔𝜈𝑓𝜈𝑔\nu(f+g)\geq\min\{\nu(f),\nu(g)\} and ν​(f​g)=ν​(f)+ν​(g)𝜈𝑓𝑔𝜈𝑓𝜈𝑔\nu(fg)=\nu(f)+\nu(g), f𝑓f and g𝑔g being elements in K∗superscript𝐾K^{*}.

A valuation as above is said to be centered at R𝑅R whenever R⊆Rν:={f∈K∗|ν​(f)≥0}∪{0}𝑅subscript𝑅𝜈assignconditional-set𝑓superscript𝐾𝜈𝑓00R\subseteq R_{\nu}:=\{f\in K^{*}|\nu(f)\geq 0\}\cup\{0\} and R∩mν(:={f∈K∗|ν​(f)>0}∪{0})annotated𝑅subscript𝑚𝜈assignabsentconditional-set𝑓superscript𝐾𝜈𝑓00R\cap m_{\nu}\left(:=\{f\in K^{*}|\nu(f)>0\}\cup\{0\}\right) coincides with the maximal ideal m𝑚m of R𝑅R. We call this type of valuations plane valuations. Assume for a while that the field k𝑘k is algebraically closed. Plane valuations have a deep geometrical meaning as the following result proves (see [38]):

Theorem 3.2.

There is a one to one correspondence between the set of plane valuations (of K𝐾K centered at R𝑅R) and the set of simple sequences of quadratic transformations of the scheme Spec R𝑅R.

What Theorem 3.2 says is that, attached to a plane valuation ν𝜈\nu, there is a unique sequence of point blowing-ups

(5) ⋯​XN+1⟶πN+1XN⟶⋯⟶X1⟶π1X0=X=Spec​R,superscript⟶subscript𝜋𝑁1⋯subscript𝑋𝑁1subscript𝑋𝑁⟶⋯⟶subscript𝑋1superscript⟶subscript𝜋1subscript𝑋0𝑋Spec𝑅\cdots X_{N+1}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\pi_{N+1}}}{{\longrightarrow}}X_{N}\longrightarrow\cdots\longrightarrow X_{1}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\pi_{1}}}{{\longrightarrow}}X_{0}=X={\rm Spec}\;R,

where πi+1subscript𝜋𝑖1\pi_{i+1} is the blowing-up of Xisubscript𝑋𝑖X_{i} at the unique closed point pisubscript𝑝𝑖p_{i} of the exceptional divisor Eisubscript𝐸𝑖E_{i} (obtained after the blowing-up πisubscript𝜋𝑖\pi_{i}) satisfying that ν𝜈\nu is centered at the local ring 𝒪Xi,pisubscript𝒪subscript𝑋𝑖subscript𝑝𝑖\mathcal{O}_{X_{i},p_{i}} (:=Ri)assignabsentsubscript𝑅𝑖(:=R_{i}). Conversely, each sequence as in (5) provides a unique plane valuation.

This fact reflects the closeness between plane valuations and germs of plane curves. It is clear that in a similar way to that explained in Section 2, we can provide a dual graph and also a HNE (with respect to a fixed regular system of parameters {u,v}𝑢𝑣\{u,v\} of the ring R𝑅R) for each plane valuation. Notice that, in this case, the sequence (5) can be either infinite or finite (what does not happen for germs of curves, although usually it is only showed the important part, that is the blowing-ups we must do until the germ is resolved). Attending to the structure of the dual graph of the sequence (5), Spivakovsky in [38] classifies the plane valuations in five types (this refines a previous classification by Zariski and it can also be refined [14]). We briefly recall the essential of this classification, since it will be useful for us. For further reference in the line of this paper, the reader can see [15, 3.3], where this classification is given in terms of the HNE of the valuations. Notice that the HNE has the advantage that it is suitable for positive characteristic and provides parametric equations of the valuations.

– Valuations whose associated sequence (5) is finite are called of TYPE A.

– A plane valuation whose sequence (5) consists, from one blowing-up on, only of blowing-ups at free points is named of TYPE B. Sequences (5) for these valuations behave as those that resolve germs of plane curves.

– TYPE C valuations are those such that their attached sequence (5) can contain finitely many blowing-ups as above, that is, with blocks of free and satellite points alternatively but it ends with infinitely many satellite blowing-ups, all of them with center at the strict transform of the same exceptional divisor.

– When the sequence (5) is as above, that is, it ends with infinitely many satellite blowing-ups, but they are not ever centered at the strict transform of the same exceptional divisor, we get TYPE D valuations.

– Finally, a valuation whose corresponding sequence (5) alternates indefinitely blowing-ups at (blocks of) free and satellite points is named to be a TYPE E valuation.

An important fact for the development of this paper is that any plane valuation can be regarded as a limit of a sequence {νi}i=1∞superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝜈𝑖𝑖1\{\nu_{i}\}_{i=1}^{\infty} of type A valuations. The valuations νisubscript𝜈𝑖\nu_{i} correspond to the divisors created by the sequence (5) attached to ν𝜈\nu. The proof is based on the fact that the ring Rνsubscript𝑅𝜈R_{\nu} is the direct limit of the sequence of rings Risubscript𝑅𝑖R_{i}.

When the valuation is centered at a two-dimensional regular local ring ℜℜ\mathfrak{R} whose residue field is not algebraically closed, the above procedure works similarly. Indeed, the valuation ring ℜνsubscriptℜ𝜈\mathfrak{R}_{\nu} of a type A valuation ν𝜈\nu is a local ring that dominates ℜℜ\mathfrak{R} and has the same quotient field as ℜℜ\mathfrak{R}. Between ℜℜ\mathfrak{R} and ℜνsubscriptℜ𝜈\mathfrak{R}_{\nu} there exists a uniquely determined sequence of mutually dominated local rings

ℜ⊂ℜ1⊂⋯⊂ℜN+1=ℜν,ℜsubscriptℜ1⋯subscriptℜ𝑁1subscriptℜ𝜈\mathfrak{R}\subset\mathfrak{R}_{1}\subset\cdots\subset\mathfrak{R}_{N+1}=\mathfrak{R}_{\nu},

which provides the blowing-up sequence. As above, the residue field of ℜνsubscriptℜ𝜈\mathfrak{R}_{\nu} is a transcendental extension of the one of ℜℜ\mathfrak{R} and the difference consists on the fact that the residue field of ℜisubscriptℜ𝑖\mathfrak{R}_{i} (1≤i≤N1𝑖𝑁1\leq i\leq N) needs not coincide with the one of ℜℜ\mathfrak{R}. However, in this paper we only consider valuations where the above residue fields always coincide and therefore we can handle our valuations as in the algebraically closed case.

Returning to the sequence {νi}i=1∞superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝜈𝑖𝑖1\{\nu_{i}\}_{i=1}^{\infty} of type A valuations converging to a plane valuation ν𝜈\nu, when we deal with a type D or E valuation ν𝜈\nu, its value group G𝐺G is a subset of the set of real numbers ℝℝ\mathbb{R} and, if we consider the normalization νi′:=νi/νi​(m)assignsubscriptsuperscript𝜈′𝑖subscript𝜈𝑖subscript𝜈𝑖𝑚\nu^{\prime}_{i}:=\nu_{i}/\nu_{i}(m) of the valuations νisubscript𝜈𝑖\nu_{i}, m𝑚m being the maximal ideal of R𝑅R and νi​(m)subscript𝜈𝑖𝑚\nu_{i}(m) the minimum of the values νi​(g)subscript𝜈𝑖𝑔\nu_{i}(g) when g𝑔g runs over m∖{0}𝑚0m\setminus\{0\}, then ν​(f)=limi→∞νi′​(f)𝜈𝑓subscript→𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝜈′𝑖𝑓\nu(f)=\lim_{i\rightarrow\infty}\nu^{\prime}_{i}(f), for all f∈K∗𝑓superscript𝐾f\in K^{*}. For type B or C valuations, G𝐺G is included in ℤ2superscriptℤ2\mathbb{Z}^{2}, ℤℤ\mathbb{Z} denoting the integer numbers, and one can understand the limit by using the Noether formula. Indeed, let ν𝜈\nu be a type A valuation, with attached sequence (5) which ends at XN+1subscript𝑋𝑁1X_{N+1} and f∈R𝑓𝑅f\in R an analytically irreducible element. Set misubscript𝑚𝑖m_{i} the maximal ideal of the local ring Risubscript𝑅𝑖R_{i} in the above sequence and assume that p0,p1,…,prsubscript𝑝0subscript𝑝1…subscript𝑝𝑟p_{0},p_{1},\ldots,p_{r}, r≤N𝑟𝑁r\leq N, are the common infinitely near points for the sequence (5) and the resolution of the germ of curve given by f𝑓f. Then ν​(mi)>0𝜈subscript𝑚𝑖0\nu(m_{i})>0 can be easily computed from the dual graph or the HNE of ν𝜈\nu (as in the case of germs of curves) and

(6) ν​(f)=∑i=0rν​(mi)​e​(pi),𝜈𝑓superscriptsubscript𝑖0𝑟𝜈subscript𝑚𝑖𝑒subscript𝑝𝑖\nu(f)=\sum_{i=0}^{r}\nu(m_{i})e(p_{i}),

where e​(pi)𝑒subscript𝑝𝑖e(p_{i}) is the multiplicity of the germ given by f𝑓f at the point pisubscript𝑝𝑖p_{i}. When ν𝜈\nu is of type B, we get the same equality, but here N=∞𝑁N=\infty and ν​(mi)∈ℤ2𝜈subscript𝑚𝑖superscriptℤ2\nu(m_{i})\in\mathbb{Z}^{2} although its first coordinate vanishes; the limit appears when r=∞𝑟r=\infty because then we set ν​(f)=(1,0)𝜈𝑓10\nu(f)=(1,0). 4. Weight functions given by plane valuations at infinity

4.1. Weight functions and plane valuations at infinity

To give the definition of weight function, first we recall some concepts related to semigroups. Assume that α,β,γ𝛼𝛽𝛾\alpha,\beta,\gamma are arbitrary elements in a commutative semigroup with zero ΓΓ\Gamma. If ≤\leq is an ordering on ΓΓ\Gamma, ≤\leq is said to be admissible if 0≤α0𝛼0\leq\alpha and, moreover, α≤β𝛼𝛽\alpha\leq\beta implies α+γ≤β+γ𝛼𝛾𝛽𝛾\alpha+\gamma\leq\beta+\gamma. On the other hand, ΓΓ\Gamma is named cancellative whenever from the equality α+β=α+γ𝛼𝛽𝛼𝛾\alpha+\beta=\alpha+\gamma one can deduce β=γ𝛽𝛾\beta=\gamma. Finally for stating the mentioned definition, stand ΓΓ\Gamma for a cancellative well-ordered commutative with zero and with admissible ordering semigroup and Γ∪{−∞}Γ\Gamma\cup\{-\infty\} for the above semigroup together with a new minimal element denoted by −∞-\infty, which satisfies α+(−∞)=−∞𝛼\alpha+(-\infty)=-\infty for all α∈Γ∪{−∞}𝛼Γ\alpha\in\Gamma\cup\{-\infty\}.

Definition 4.1.

A weight function from a k𝑘k-algebra A𝐴A onto a semigroup Γ∪{−∞}Γ\Gamma\cup\{-\infty\} as above is a mapping w:A⟶Γ∪{−∞}:𝑤⟶𝐴Γw:A\longrightarrow\Gamma\cup\{-\infty\} such that, for p,q∈A𝑝𝑞𝐴p,q\in A, the following statements must be satisfied:

  1. (1)

    w​(p)=−∞𝑤𝑝w(p)=-\infty if and only if p=0𝑝0p=0;

  2. (2)

    w​(a​p)=w​(p)𝑤𝑎𝑝𝑤𝑝w(ap)=w(p) for all nonzero element a∈k𝑎𝑘a\in k;

  3. (3)

    w​(p+q)≤max⁡{w​(p),w​(q)}𝑤𝑝𝑞𝑤𝑝𝑤𝑞w(p+q)\leq\max\{w(p),w(q)\};

  4. (4)

    If w​(p)=w​(q)𝑤𝑝𝑤𝑞w(p)=w(q), then there exists a nonzero element a∈k∗𝑎superscript𝑘a\in k^{*} such that w​(p−a​q)<w​(q)𝑤𝑝𝑎𝑞𝑤𝑞w(p-aq)<w(q);

  5. (5)

    w​(p​q)=w​(p)+w​(q)𝑤𝑝𝑞𝑤𝑝𝑤𝑞w(pq)=w(p)+w(q).

When the last condition is not imposed, we get the definition of order function. It is clear that if w𝑤w is a weight function, then the triple (A,w,Γ)𝐴𝑤Γ(A,w,\Gamma) is an order domain over k𝑘k (see, for instance, [16] for the definition of order domain).

The next result, proved in [15, Proposition 2.2], shows how to get weight functions from valuations.

Proposition 4.2.

Let 𝔎𝔎\mathfrak{K} be the quotient field of a Noetherian regular local domain ℜℜ\mathfrak{R} with maximal 𝔪𝔪\mathfrak{m}. Let ν:𝔎∗→𝔊:𝜈→superscript𝔎𝔊\nu:\mathfrak{K}^{*}\rightarrow\mathfrak{G} be a valuation of 𝔎𝔎\mathfrak{K} which is centered at ℜℜ\mathfrak{R}. Assume that the canonical embedding of the field 𝔨=ℜ/𝔪𝔨ℜ𝔪\mathfrak{k}=\mathfrak{R}/\mathfrak{m} into the field ℜν/𝔪νsubscriptℜ𝜈subscript𝔪𝜈\mathfrak{R}_{\nu}/\mathfrak{m}_{\nu} is an isomorphism.

Set w:𝔎∗→𝔊:𝑤→superscript𝔎𝔊w:\mathfrak{K}^{*}\rightarrow\mathfrak{G} the mapping given by w​(f)=−ν​(f)𝑤𝑓𝜈𝑓w(f)=-\nu(f), f∈𝔎∗𝑓superscript𝔎f\in\mathfrak{K}^{*}. If 𝔄⊆𝔎∗𝔄superscript𝔎\mathfrak{A}\subseteq\mathfrak{K}^{*} is a 𝔨𝔨\mathfrak{k}-algebra such that w​(𝔄)𝑤𝔄w(\mathfrak{A}) is a cancellative, commutative, free of torsion, well-ordered semigroup with zero, ΓΓ\Gamma, where the associated ordering is admissible, then w:𝔄⟶w​(𝔄)∪{−∞}:𝑤⟶𝔄𝑤𝔄w:\mathfrak{A}\longrightarrow w(\mathfrak{A})\cup\{-\infty\}, w​(0)=−∞𝑤0w(0)=-\infty, is a weight function.

Recall that p∈ℙ2𝑝superscriptℙ2p\in\mathbb{P}^{2}, R=𝒪ℙ2,p𝑅subscript𝒪superscriptℙ2𝑝R=\mathcal{O}_{\mathbb{P}^{2},p} and K𝐾K is the quotient field of R𝑅R. The isomorphism R/m≅Rν/mν𝑅𝑚subscript𝑅𝜈subscript𝑚𝜈R/m\cong R_{\nu}/m_{\nu} happens for any plane valuation ν𝜈\nu except for those of type A.

Now, we are going to introduce another fundamental concept for us: plane valuation at infinity. To do it, we start by stating the concept of general element of a type A plane valuation. As we have said, these valuations are the unique whose corresponding sequence of point blowing-ups is finite. In fact, they are defined by the last created exceptional divisor and, by this reason, they are also named divisorial valuations. Concretely, with the notation in Section 3, if πN+1subscript𝜋𝑁1\pi_{N+1} is the last blowing-up in the sequence (5) given by a divisorial valuation ν𝜈\nu, then ν𝜈\nu is the mNsubscript𝑚𝑁m_{N}-adic valuation, mNsubscript𝑚𝑁m_{N} being the maximal ideal of the ring RNsubscript𝑅𝑁R_{N}.

Definition 4.3.

Let ν𝜈\nu be a divisorial valuation. An element f𝑓f in the maximal ideal of R𝑅R is called to be a general element of ν𝜈\nu if the germ of curve given by f𝑓f is analytically irreducible, its strict transform in XN+1subscript𝑋𝑁1X_{N+1} is smooth and meets EN+1subscript𝐸𝑁1E_{N+1} transversely at a non-singular point of the exceptional divisor of the sequence (5) attached to ν𝜈\nu.

General elements are useful to compute plane valuations. Indeed, if f∈R𝑓𝑅f\in R, then

ν​(f)= min {(f,g)|g is a general element of ν}, 𝜈𝑓 min {(f,g)|g is a general element of ν}, \nu(f)=\mbox{ min $\{(f,g)|g$ is a general element of $\nu\},$ }

where (f,g)𝑓𝑔(f,g) stands for the intersection multiplicity of the germs of curve given by f𝑓f and g𝑔g.

Definition 4.4.

A plane divisorial valuation at infinity is a plane divisorial valuation of K𝐾K centered at R𝑅R that admits, as a general element, an element in R𝑅R providing the germ at p𝑝p of some curve with only one place at infinity (p𝑝p being its point at infinity).

Definition 4.5.

A plane valuation ν𝜈\nu of K𝐾K centered at R𝑅R is said to be at infinity whenever it is a limit of plane divisorial valuations at infinity. More explicitly, set {νi}i=1∞superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝜈𝑖𝑖1\{\nu_{i}\}_{i=1}^{\infty} the set of plane divisorial valuations, corresponding to divisors Eisubscript𝐸𝑖E_{i}, that appear in the sequence (5) given by ν𝜈\nu. ν𝜈\nu will be at infinity if, for any index i0subscript𝑖0i_{0}, there is some i>i0𝑖subscript𝑖0i>i_{0} such that νisubscript𝜈𝑖\nu_{i} is a plane divisorial valuation at infinity.

Afterwards, we shall see that, as it happens for type A valuations, type B ones are not suitable for our purposes. So we exclude them of the next definition.

Definition 4.6.

Let ν𝜈\nu be a plane valuation at infinity that is neither of type A nor of type B. A sequence of polynomials P={qi​(x,y)}i≥0𝑃subscriptsubscript𝑞𝑖𝑥𝑦𝑖0P=\{q_{i}(x,y)\}_{i\geq 0} in k​[x,y]𝑘𝑥𝑦k[x,y] is a family of approximates for ν𝜈\nu whenever each plane curve C𝐶C with only one place at infinity providing a general element of some of the plane divisorial valuations at infinity converging to ν𝜈\nu admits some subset of P𝑃P as a family of approximates and P𝑃P is minimal with this property.

4.2. δ𝛿\delta-sequences

Now, we introduce the most important concept of this paper: the one of δ𝛿\delta-sequence. First of all, notice that if S𝑆S is an ordered commutative semigroup in ℝℝ\mathbb{R} (naturally ordered) or ℤ2superscriptℤ2\mathbb{Z}^{2} (with the lexicographical ordering, that is α>β𝛼𝛽\alpha>\beta if and only if the left-most nonzero entry of α−β𝛼𝛽\alpha-\beta is positive) and γ0>γ1>0subscript𝛾0subscript𝛾10\gamma_{0}>\gamma_{1}>0 are in S𝑆S such that j​γ1>γ0𝑗subscript𝛾1subscript𝛾0j\gamma_{1}>\gamma_{0} for some integer number j>0𝑗0j>0, then we can set γ0=m1​γ1+γ2subscript𝛾0subscript𝑚1subscript𝛾1subscript𝛾2\gamma_{0}=m_{1}\gamma_{1}+\gamma_{2} with m1∈ℕ>0subscript𝑚1subscriptℕabsent0m_{1}\in\mathbb{N}_{>0}, γ2subscript𝛾2\gamma_{2} in ℝℝ\mathbb{R} or ℤ2superscriptℤ2\mathbb{Z}^{2} and 0≤γ2<γ10subscript𝛾2subscript𝛾10\leq\gamma_{2}<\gamma_{1} (note that m1subscript𝑚1m_{1} and γ2subscript𝛾2\gamma_{2} are uniquely determined by these conditions). Let us see that δ𝛿\delta-sequences ΔΔ\Delta in ℤ2superscriptℤ2\mathbb{Z}^{2} are intimately related to type C plane valuations at infinity. δ𝛿\delta-sequences in ℚℚ\mathbb{Q} (respectively, in ℝℝ\mathbb{R}) are related with valuations at infinity of type E (respectively, D). As a consequence of the last paragraphs, we have proved the following

Proposition 4.8.

Let Δ={δi}i=0r,r≤∞formulae-sequenceΔsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝛿𝑖𝑖0𝑟𝑟\Delta=\{\delta_{i}\}_{i=0}^{r},r\leq\infty, be a δ𝛿\delta-sequence in ℤ2superscriptℤ2\mathbb{Z}^{2} (respectively, in ℚℚ\mathbb{Q}) (respectively, in ℝℝ\mathbb{R}). Then, there exists a plane valuation at infinity νΔsubscript𝜈Δ\nu_{\Delta} of type C (respectively, E) (respectively, D) and a family {qi​(x,y)}i=0rsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑞𝑖𝑥𝑦𝑖0𝑟\{q_{i}(x,y)\}_{i=0}^{r} of approximates for νΔsubscript𝜈Δ\nu_{\Delta} such that −νΔ​(qi​(x,y))=δisubscript𝜈Δsubscript𝑞𝑖𝑥𝑦subscript𝛿𝑖-\nu_{\Delta}(q_{i}(x,y))=\delta_{i} for all index i𝑖i.

Notice that we have chosen a concrete valuation νΔsubscript𝜈Δ\nu_{\Delta}, but this election needs not be unique since we could take another suitable families of approximates. Moreover, even when we have fixed certain type of approximates, we have infinitely many possibilities for our qisubscript𝑞𝑖q_{i}, 1<i<r1𝑖𝑟1<i<r, according the parameters tisubscript𝑡𝑖t_{i} we set in (3).

Remark. In this paper, generically, we shall name δ𝛿\delta-sequence to any of the δ𝛿\delta-sequences (in ℤ2superscriptℤ2\mathbb{Z}^{2}, ℚℚ\mathbb{Q} or ℝℝ\mathbb{R}) above defined. Due to their definition, we can apply the Euclidian algorithm as we described at the beginning of this subsection to the values mjsubscript𝑚𝑗m_{j}, ejsubscript𝑒𝑗e_{j}, 0≤j<g0𝑗𝑔0\leq j<g, (g=∞𝑔g=\infty in the case in ℚℚ\mathbb{Q}) defined as in page 2.4 and computed from the δ𝛿\delta-sequences (newly with the Euclidian algorithm). Case 3) happens for δ𝛿\delta-sequences in ℤ2superscriptℤ2\mathbb{Z}^{2}, since we get γi−1=(1,0)subscript𝛾𝑖110\gamma_{i-1}=(1,0) and γi=(0,1)subscript𝛾𝑖01\gamma_{i}=(0,1), Case 2) holds for δ𝛿\delta-sequences in ℝℝ\mathbb{R} and, for δ𝛿\delta-sequences in ℚℚ\mathbb{Q}, we have an indefinite iteration of Case 1) . Along this paper, we shall use freely the notation mjsubscript𝑚𝑗m_{j}, ejsubscript𝑒𝑗e_{j}, djsubscript𝑑𝑗d_{j}, 0≤j≤g−10𝑗𝑔10\leq j\leq g-1, adapted to the corresponding δ𝛿\delta-sequence.

Table 1 summarizes briefly the relation among the different types of δ𝛿\delta-sequences and their corresponding families of approximates and valuations.

Remark. Notice that we have no definition of δ𝛿\delta-sequence related to type B valuations. This concept could be defined following the same line of this paper; however it would not be useful for us, since we would get δ𝛿\delta-sequences Δ={δ0,δ1,…,δg+1}Δsubscript𝛿0subscript𝛿1…subscript𝛿𝑔1\Delta=\{\delta_{0},\delta_{1},\ldots,\delta_{g+1}\} where δi∈{0}⊕ℕ>0subscript𝛿𝑖direct-sum0subscriptℕabsent0\delta_{i}\in\{0\}\oplus\mathbb{N}_{>0} (0≤i≤g0𝑖𝑔0\leq i\leq g) and δg+1=(−1,a)subscript𝛿𝑔11𝑎\delta_{g+1}=(-1,a), a∈ℕ>0𝑎subscriptℕabsent0a\in\mathbb{N}_{>0}, and then SΔsubscript𝑆ΔS_{\Delta} would not be well-ordered (for the lexicographical ordering).

Next, we state the main result of the paper.

4.3. Construction of weight functions attached to valuations at infinity

To end this section, we provide algorithms to get δ𝛿\delta-sequences of every described type. Recall that the ordering of the semigroup SΔsubscript𝑆ΔS_{\Delta} is given by the lexicographical one in ℤ2superscriptℤ2\mathbb{Z}^{2} for type C weight functions and by the natural ordering in ℝℝ\mathbb{R} (respectively, ℚℚ\mathbb{Q}) for type D (respectively, type E) weight functions. To get a basis of the vector space Oαsubscript𝑂𝛼O_{\alpha}, α∈SΔ𝛼subscript𝑆Δ\alpha\in S_{\Delta}, we only need to compute approximates {qi}i=1rsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑞𝑖𝑖1𝑟\{q_{i}\}_{i=1}^{r} for −wΔsubscript𝑤Δ-w_{\Delta} as we have described to prove Proposition 4.8 (see (3)) and fix a unique polynomial qβ:=∏i=1mqiγiassignsubscript𝑞𝛽superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑖1𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑖subscript𝛾𝑖q_{\beta}:=\prod_{i=1}^{m}q_{i}^{\gamma_{i}} with β=∑i=1mγi​δi𝛽superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚subscript𝛾𝑖subscript𝛿𝑖\beta=\sum_{i=1}^{m}\gamma_{i}\delta_{i} for each β∈SΔ𝛽subscript𝑆Δ\beta\in S_{\Delta} such that β≤α𝛽𝛼\beta\leq\alpha. Then, the set {qβ}β≤αsubscriptsubscript𝑞𝛽𝛽𝛼\{q_{\beta}\}_{\beta\leq\alpha} will be a basis as desired.

4.3.1. δ𝛿\delta-sequences in ℕ>0subscriptℕabsent0\mathbb{N}_{>0}.

The concept of δ𝛿\delta-sequence in ℕ>0subscriptℕabsent0\mathbb{N}_{>0} is an important tool in this paper because it supports our general definition of δ𝛿\delta-sequence. We conclude this section by showing how to construct type E weight functions and giving some examples.

4.3.4. Type E weight functions.

A procedure for obtaining this type of weight functions is, starting with a given δ𝛿\delta-sequence in ℕ>0subscriptℕabsent0\mathbb{N}_{>0}, to reproduce indefinitely the procedure given in Subsection 4.3.1 but with the following extra condition in Step 2: z​δg<δg+1′𝑧subscript𝛿𝑔subscriptsuperscript𝛿′𝑔1z\delta_{g}<\delta^{\prime}_{g+1}. This condition assures that, normalizing the successively obtained δ𝛿\delta-sequences, one gets an increasing δ𝛿\delta-sequence in ℚℚ\mathbb{Q} (with the natural ordering) and, then, it generates a well-ordered semigroup. For instance, considering only values of z𝑧z which are relatively prime with δgsubscript𝛿𝑔\delta_{g} and taking δg+1′=(z+1)​δgsubscriptsuperscript𝛿′𝑔1𝑧1subscript𝛿𝑔\delta^{\prime}_{g+1}=(z+1)\delta_{g} in Step 2, the above condition will be satisfied.

5. Evaluation codes given by δ𝛿\delta-sequences.

5.1. Generalized telescopic semigroups

A semigroup S⊆ℕ≥0𝑆subscriptℕabsent0S\subseteq\mathbb{N}_{\geq 0} is called to be telescopic if it is spanned by a finite sequence of positive integers {α1,α2,…,αr}subscript𝛼1subscript𝛼2…subscript𝛼𝑟\{\alpha_{1},\alpha_{2},\ldots,\alpha_{r}\} (named telescopic sequence) such that gcd⁡(α1,α2,…,αr)=1subscript𝛼1subscript𝛼2…subscript𝛼𝑟1\gcd(\alpha_{1},\alpha_{2},\ldots,\alpha_{r})=1 and αi/gcd⁡(α1,α2,…,αi)subscript𝛼𝑖subscript𝛼1subscript𝛼2…subscript𝛼𝑖\alpha_{i}/\gcd(\alpha_{1},\alpha_{2},\ldots,\alpha_{i}) belongs to the semigroup generated by the set {α1/gcd⁡(α1,α2,…,αi−1),…,αi−1/gcd⁡(α1,α2,…,αi−1)}subscript𝛼1subscript𝛼1subscript𝛼2…subscript𝛼𝑖1…subscript𝛼𝑖1subscript𝛼1subscript𝛼2…subscript𝛼𝑖1\{\alpha_{1}/\gcd(\alpha_{1},\alpha_{2},\ldots,\alpha_{i-1}),\ldots,\alpha_{i-1}/\gcd(\alpha_{1},\alpha_{2},\ldots,\alpha_{i-1})\}. An important property of these semigroups is that each element α∈S𝛼𝑆\alpha\in S can be uniquely expressed in the form α=∑i=1rai​αi𝛼superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑟subscript𝑎𝑖subscript𝛼𝑖\alpha=\sum_{i=1}^{r}a_{i}\alpha_{i}, provided that a1≥0subscript𝑎10a_{1}\geq 0 and 0≤ai<gcd⁡(α1,α2,…,αi−1)/gcd⁡(α1,α2,…,αi)0subscript𝑎𝑖subscript𝛼1subscript𝛼2…subscript𝛼𝑖1subscript𝛼1subscript𝛼2…subscript𝛼𝑖0\leq a_{i}<\gcd(\alpha_{1},\alpha_{2},\ldots,\alpha_{i-1})/\gcd(\alpha_{1},\alpha_{2},\ldots,\alpha_{i}) (2≤i≤r2𝑖𝑟2\leq i\leq r). This fact has importance when one desires to bound the minimum distance of the dual codes of the evaluation ones given by classical weight functions [19].

The following definition is a natural enlargement in such a way that the mentioned property is preserved.

Definition 5.1.

A generalized telescopic semigroup in ℤ2superscriptℤ2\mathbb{Z}^{2} (respectively, ℚℚ\mathbb{Q}) (respectively, ℝℝ\mathbb{R}) is a cancellative well-ordered commutative with zero semigroup spanned by a set A={αi}i=1r𝐴superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝛼𝑖𝑖1𝑟A=\{\alpha_{i}\}_{i=1}^{r} such that:

(ℤ2superscriptℤ2\mathbb{Z}^{2}):

(ℚℚ\mathbb{Q}):

(Respectively, r=∞𝑟r=\infty, A⊂ℚ𝐴ℚA\subset\mathbb{Q} (natural order) and for each i>1𝑖1i>1 there exists a telescopic sequence, {βj}j=1isuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝛽𝑗𝑗1𝑖\{\beta_{j}\}_{j=1}^{i}, such that the morphism of ordered semigroups ρ:⟨α1,…​αi−1⟩⟶⟨β1,…​βi−1⟩:𝜌⟶subscript𝛼1…subscript𝛼𝑖1subscript𝛽1…subscript𝛽𝑖1\rho:\langle\alpha_{1},\ldots\alpha_{i-1}\rangle\longrightarrow\langle\beta_{1},\ldots\beta_{i-1}\rangle, ρ​(αj)=βj𝜌subscript𝛼𝑗subscript𝛽𝑗\rho(\alpha_{j})=\beta_{j}, are isomorphisms.)

(ℝ)\mathbb{R}):

Generically, a generalized telescopic semigroup in ℤ2superscriptℤ2\mathbb{Z}^{2}, ℚℚ\mathbb{Q} or ℝℝ\mathbb{R} will be named simply a generalized telescopic semigroup.

Proposition 5.2.

Let S𝑆S be a generalized telescopic semigroup spanned by {αi}i=1rsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝛼𝑖𝑖1𝑟\{\alpha_{i}\}_{i=1}^{r}, r≤∞𝑟r\leq\infty, as above. Then any element α∈S𝛼𝑆\alpha\in S can be written in a unique way of the form

(11) α=∑i=1sai​αi,𝛼superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑠subscript𝑎𝑖subscript𝛼𝑖\alpha=\sum_{i=1}^{s}a_{i}\alpha_{i},

where s<r+1𝑠𝑟1s<r+1, a1,as≥0subscript𝑎1subscript𝑎𝑠0a_{1},a_{s}\geq 0 and 0≤ai<gcd⁡(α1,α2,…,αi−1)/gcd⁡(α1,α2,…,αi)0subscript𝑎𝑖subscript𝛼1subscript𝛼2…subscript𝛼𝑖1subscript𝛼1subscript𝛼2…subscript𝛼𝑖0\leq a_{i}<\gcd(\alpha_{1},\alpha_{2},\ldots,\alpha_{i-1})/\gcd(\alpha_{1},\alpha_{2},\ldots,\alpha_{i}) (2≤i<s2𝑖𝑠2\leq i<s) and we have put gcd⁡(α1,α2,…,αj):=gcd⁡(β1,β2,…,βj)assignsubscript𝛼1subscript𝛼2…subscript𝛼𝑗subscript𝛽1subscript𝛽2…subscript𝛽𝑗\gcd(\alpha_{1},\alpha_{2},\ldots,\alpha_{j}):=\gcd(\beta_{1},\beta_{2},\ldots,\beta_{j}) (1≤j<r1𝑗𝑟1\leq j<r), βjsubscript𝛽𝑗\beta_{j} being as in Definition 5.1.

Proof.

First let us see the case when r𝑟r is finite. Due to the nature of the generators of S𝑆S, when we set α=∑i=1rai​αi𝛼superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑟subscript𝑎𝑖subscript𝛼𝑖\alpha=\sum_{i=1}^{r}a_{i}\alpha_{i}, it holds that the value arsubscript𝑎𝑟a_{r} must be unique, since either it is the unique nonnegative integer such that α−ar​αr𝛼subscript𝑎𝑟subscript𝛼𝑟\alpha-a_{r}\alpha_{r} is on the line L𝐿L when S⊂ℤ2𝑆superscriptℤ2S\subset\mathbb{Z}^{2} or it is the unique nonnegative integer such that α−ar​αr𝛼subscript𝑎𝑟subscript𝛼𝑟\alpha-a_{r}\alpha_{r} is a rational value whenever S⊂ℝ𝑆ℝS\subset\mathbb{R}. Thus, if we set a=gcd⁡(α1,α2,…,αr−1)𝑎subscript𝛼1subscript𝛼2…subscript𝛼𝑟1a=\gcd(\alpha_{1},\alpha_{2},\ldots,\alpha_{r-1}), it happens that ⟨α1/a,α2/a,…,αr−1/a⟩subscript𝛼1𝑎subscript𝛼2𝑎…subscript𝛼𝑟1𝑎\langle\alpha_{1}/a,\alpha_{2}/a,\ldots,\alpha_{r-1}/a\rangle is like a telescopic semigroup and the fact

provides the desired property.

When r𝑟r is infinite, the proof runs similarly. Indeed, assume that α=∑i=1sbi​αi𝛼superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑠subscript𝑏𝑖subscript𝛼𝑖\alpha=\sum_{i=1}^{s}b_{i}\alpha_{i}. Remark. A δ𝛿\delta-sequence in ℕ>0subscriptℕabsent0\mathbb{N}_{>0} generates a telescopic semigroup. We have just enlarged this last concept in such a way that any δ𝛿\delta-sequence ΔΔ\Delta generates a generalized telescopic semigroup and so SΔsubscript𝑆ΔS_{\Delta} satisfies the property given in the above proposition.

Proposition 5.4.

Let Δ={δi}i=0rΔsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝛿𝑖𝑖0𝑟\Delta=\{\delta_{i}\}_{i=0}^{r}, r≤∞𝑟r\leq\infty, be a δ𝛿\delta-sequence and {Eα}α∈SΔsubscriptsubscript𝐸𝛼𝛼subscript𝑆Δ\{E_{\alpha}\}_{\alpha\in S_{\Delta}} and {Cα}α∈SΔsubscriptsubscript𝐶𝛼𝛼subscript𝑆Δ\{C_{\alpha}\}_{\alpha\in S_{\Delta}} the corresponding evaluation and dual codes for some fixed evaluation morphism e​v𝑒𝑣ev. dSΔ​(α)={min0≤j≤B⁡{[χ​(Aj∗)+1−1+∑i=0g−1(ni−1)​δi∗2]​(j+1)}if s=g is finiteχ​(α∗)+1−(1+∑i=0s(ni−1)​δi∗)/2otherwise,subscript𝑑subscript𝑆Δ𝛼casessubscript0𝑗𝐵delimited-[]𝜒superscriptsubscript𝐴𝑗11superscriptsubscript𝑖0𝑔1subscript𝑛𝑖1subscriptsuperscript𝛿𝑖2𝑗1if s=g is finite𝜒superscript𝛼11superscriptsubscript𝑖0𝑠subscript𝑛𝑖1superscriptsubscript𝛿𝑖2otherwise,d_{S_{\Delta}}(\alpha)=\left\{\begin{array}[]{ll}\min_{0\leq j\leq B}\left\{[\chi(A_{j}^{*})+1-\frac{1+\sum_{i=0}^{g-1}(n_{i}-1)\delta^{*}_{i}}{2}]\;(j+1)\right\}&\mbox{if $s=g$ is finite}\\ \chi(\alpha^{*})+1-\left(1+\sum_{i=0}^{s}(n_{i}-1)\delta_{i}^{*}\right)/2&\mbox{otherwise,}\end{array}\right.

where B𝐵B is as above, n0=1subscript𝑛01n_{0}=1 and the remaining nisubscript𝑛𝑖n_{i} are the usual ones for ΔΔ\Delta.

Proof.

First part can be proved by taking into account that when one considers weight functions with values in a semigroup S∗superscript𝑆S^{*} in ℕ≥0subscriptℕabsent0\mathbb{N}_{\geq 0} spanned by values whose greatest common divisor is one and with g𝑔g gaps, then the Feng-Rao distance d​(α)𝑑𝛼d(\alpha) of the dual evaluation code associated with α∈S∗𝛼superscript𝑆\alpha\in S^{*} is larger than or equal to its Goppa distance. Last part is a consequence of the computation given in [19] of the number of gaps of a telescopic semigroup. ∎

Finally, we prove that the semigroups SΔsubscript𝑆ΔS_{\Delta} corresponding to δ𝛿\delta-sequences ΔΔ\Delta providing weight functions of type C are simplicial. This one will be a useful property since there exists an algorithm given by Ruano in [32] for computing the Feng-Rao distance d​(α)𝑑𝛼d(\alpha) of codes Cαsubscript𝐶𝛼C_{\alpha} associated with order functions with simplicial image semigroup included in (ℕ≥0)rsuperscriptsubscriptℕabsent0𝑟(\mathbb{N}_{\geq 0})^{r}, r≥1𝑟1r\geq 1. Recall what this concept means. Let S𝑆S be a semigroup included in (ℕ≥0)rsuperscriptsubscriptℕabsent0𝑟(\mathbb{N}_{\geq 0})^{r}, r≥1𝑟1r\geq 1. Setting U𝑈U an indeterminate, the k𝑘k-algebra k​[S]:=⨁α∈Sk​Uαassign𝑘delimited-[]𝑆subscriptdirect-sum𝛼𝑆𝑘superscript𝑈𝛼k[S]:=\bigoplus_{\alpha\in S}kU^{\alpha}, where the product of polynomials is induced by (a​Uα)​(b​Uβ)=(a​b)​Uα+β𝑎superscript𝑈𝛼𝑏superscript𝑈𝛽𝑎𝑏superscript𝑈𝛼𝛽(aU^{\alpha})(bU^{\beta})=(ab)U^{\alpha+\beta}, a,b∈k𝑎𝑏𝑘a,b\in k and α,β∈S𝛼𝛽𝑆\alpha,\beta\in S is named the k𝑘k-algebra of the semigroup S𝑆S. Now, set CSsubscript𝐶𝑆C_{S} the cone in ℝrsuperscriptℝ𝑟\mathbb{R}^{r} spanned by S𝑆S. CSsubscript𝐶𝑆C_{S} is a strongly convex cone. We shall say that S𝑆S is simplicial whenever the dimension of the k𝑘k-algebra k​[S]𝑘delimited-[]𝑆k[S] coincides with the number of extremal rays of the cone CSsubscript𝐶𝑆C_{S}.

Proposition 5.5.

The semigroup SΔsubscript𝑆ΔS_{\Delta} of a δ𝛿\delta-sequence Δ={δi}i=0g⊆(ℕ≥0)2Δsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝛿𝑖𝑖0𝑔superscriptsubscriptℕabsent02\Delta=\{\delta_{i}\}_{i=0}^{g}\subseteq(\mathbb{N}_{\geq 0})^{2} of type C is simplicial.

Proof.

Since ΔΔ\Delta is of type C, the number of extremal rays of CSΔsubscript𝐶subscript𝑆ΔC_{S_{\Delta}} is two. Now, set k​[V0,V1,…,Vg]𝑘subscript𝑉0subscript𝑉1…subscript𝑉𝑔k[V_{0},V_{1},\ldots,V_{g}] the polynomial ring in g+1𝑔1g+1 indeterminates and set

ψ:k​[V0,V1,…,Vg]→k​[SΔ]:𝜓→𝑘subscript𝑉0subscript𝑉1…subscript𝑉𝑔𝑘delimited-[]subscript𝑆Δ\psi:k[V_{0},V_{1},\ldots,V_{g}]\rightarrow k[S_{\Delta}]

the morphism of k𝑘k-algebras given by ψ​(Vi)=Uδi𝜓subscript𝑉𝑖superscript𝑈subscript𝛿𝑖\psi(V_{i})=U^{\delta_{i}}. ψ𝜓\psi is an epimorphism. For 0<i<g0𝑖𝑔0<i<g, consider the unique expression

ni​δi=∑j=0i−1ai​j​δj,subscript𝑛𝑖subscript𝛿𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑗0𝑖1subscript𝑎𝑖𝑗subscript𝛿𝑗n_{i}\delta_{i}=\sum_{j=0}^{i-1}a_{ij}\delta_{j},

such that ai​0>0subscript𝑎𝑖00a_{i0}>0 and 0≤ai​j<nj0subscript𝑎𝑖𝑗subscript𝑛𝑗0\leq a_{ij}<n_{j} for the remaining indices j𝑗j, being njsubscript𝑛𝑗n_{j} the usual number associated with ΔΔ\Delta. Then, the proof follows by taking into account that the kernel of ψ𝜓\psi, I𝐼I, is the ideal of k​[V0,V1,…,Vg]𝑘subscript𝑉0subscript𝑉1…subscript𝑉𝑔k[V_{0},V_{1},\ldots,V_{g}] spanned by the set G:={Vini−∏j=0i−1Vjai​j}0<i<gassign𝐺subscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑉𝑖subscript𝑛𝑖superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑗0𝑖1superscriptsubscript𝑉𝑗subscript𝑎𝑖𝑗0𝑖𝑔G:=\{V_{i}^{n_{i}}-\prod_{j=0}^{i-1}V_{j}^{a_{ij}}\}_{0<i<g} and therefore k​[S]≅k​[V0,V1,…,Vg]/I𝑘delimited-[]𝑆𝑘subscript𝑉0subscript𝑉1…subscript𝑉𝑔𝐼k[S]\cong k[V_{0},V_{1},\ldots,V_{g}]/I whose dimension is also two.

Only remains to prove that G𝐺G spans I𝐼I. To do it, it suffices to notice that I𝐼I is generated by the binomials A−B∈k​[V0,V1,…,Vg]𝐴𝐵𝑘subscript𝑉0subscript𝑉1…subscript𝑉𝑔A-B\in k[V_{0},V_{1},\ldots,V_{g}] such that A𝐴A and B𝐵B are homogeneous monomials with coefficient 1 and ψ​(A−B)=0𝜓𝐴𝐵0\psi(A-B)=0. These monomials can be represented by the set ℬℬ\mathcal{B} of pairs (a,b)∈(ℕ≥0g+1)2𝑎𝑏superscriptsuperscriptsubscriptℕabsent0𝑔12(a,b)\in(\mathbb{N}_{\geq 0}^{g+1})^{2} representing the exponents of both monomials. ℬℬ\mathcal{B} gives rise to a congruence, that is an equivalence binary relation such that if c∈ℕ≥0g+1𝑐superscriptsubscriptℕabsent0𝑔1c\in\mathbb{N}_{\geq 0}^{g+1} and (a,b)∈ℬ𝑎𝑏ℬ(a,b)\in\mathcal{B}, then (a+c,b+c)∈ℬ𝑎𝑐𝑏𝑐ℬ(a+c,b+c)\in\mathcal{B}. As the set 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D} of pairs given by the exponents of the elements in G𝐺G, satisfies that ℬℬ\mathcal{B} corresponds to the smallest congruence containing 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}, we get that G𝐺G spans the ideal I𝐼I, which concludes the proof (see the proof of [15, Theorem 5.2] for a more detailed explanation of a close result). ∎

5.3. Examples

First of all, we prove that Reed-Solomon codes can be regarded as particular cases of evaluation codes attached to type C weight functions.

Proposition 5.6.

Consider the finite field k=𝔽q𝑘subscript𝔽𝑞k=\mathbb{F}_{q}, a δ𝛿\delta-sequence in ℤ2superscriptℤ2\mathbb{Z}^{2}, Δ={δ0=(p1,p2),δ1=(q1,q2)}Δformulae-sequencesubscript𝛿0subscript𝑝1subscript𝑝2subscript𝛿1subscript𝑞1subscript𝑞2\Delta=\{\delta_{0}=(p_{1},p_{2}),\delta_{1}=(q_{1},q_{2})\}, and the epimorphism e​v𝑒𝑣ev given by evaluating d≤q−1𝑑𝑞1d\leq q-1 points in a line in 𝔽q2superscriptsubscript𝔽𝑞2\mathbb{F}_{q}^{2}. Then the family of evaluation codes {Eα}α∈SΔsubscriptsubscript𝐸𝛼𝛼subscript𝑆Δ\{E_{\alpha}\}_{\alpha\in S_{\Delta}} is the family of length d𝑑d Reed-Solomon codes associated with 𝔽qsubscript𝔽𝑞\mathbb{F}_{q}.

Proof.

Assume that we evaluate points at the line given by y−a​x−b=0𝑦𝑎𝑥𝑏0y-ax-b=0; a,b∈𝔽q𝑎𝑏subscript𝔽𝑞a,b\in\mathbb{F}_{q}. Our approximates are x𝑥x and y𝑦y and, in order to span the spaces Oαsubscript𝑂𝛼O_{\alpha}, we must use monomials in x𝑥x and y𝑦y. When we evaluate a monomial xm​ynsuperscript𝑥𝑚superscript𝑦𝑛x^{m}y^{n}, this corresponds to evaluate xm​(a​x+b)nsuperscript𝑥𝑚superscript𝑎𝑥𝑏𝑛x^{m}(ax+b)^{n}, that is a polynomial of degree m+n𝑚𝑛m+n in the indeterminate x𝑥x. p1≥q1subscript𝑝1subscript𝑞1p_{1}\geq q_{1} and, since δ1<2​δ1<⋯<l​δ1subscript𝛿12subscript𝛿1⋯𝑙subscript𝛿1\delta_{1}<2\delta_{1}<\cdots<l\delta_{1} are elements in SΔsubscript𝑆ΔS_{\Delta}, when we consider El​δ1subscript𝐸𝑙subscript𝛿1E_{l\delta_{1}}, l∈ℕ>0𝑙subscriptℕabsent0l\in\mathbb{N}_{>0}, one evaluates among others a monomial of degree l𝑙l in x𝑥x. So, it suffices to show that no monomial of degree larger than l𝑙l appears in Ol​δ1subscript𝑂𝑙subscript𝛿1O_{l\delta_{1}}. That is, we must prove that r​δ0+s​δ1<t​δ1𝑟subscript𝛿0𝑠subscript𝛿1𝑡subscript𝛿1r\delta_{0}+s\delta_{1}<t\delta_{1}, r,s∈ℕ≥0𝑟𝑠subscriptℕabsent0r,s\in\mathbb{N}_{\geq 0}, implies r+s≤t𝑟𝑠𝑡r+s\leq t and this is true because then r​p1+s​q1≤t​q1𝑟subscript𝑝1𝑠subscript𝑞1𝑡subscript𝑞1rp_{1}+sq_{1}\leq tq_{1} and thus (s−t)​q1≤−r​p1≤−r​q1𝑠𝑡subscript𝑞1𝑟subscript𝑝1𝑟subscript𝑞1(s-t)q_{1}\leq-rp_{1}\leq-rq_{1}, which concludes the proof when q1>0subscript𝑞10q_{1}>0. Otherwise the proof follows because then r=0𝑟0r=0. ∎
